posts.cooked: I solo develop Team 236’s website located at https://team236.github.io/ and am seeking general feedback for improvements. Anything is much appreciated.

posts.name: Rhett Adam
posts.cooked: Put all buttons leading to different pages into a visible navigation bar. On mobile, this can be condensed into a hamburger icon that opens a menu containing all your navigation items.
Smart, will do!

posts.name: MARS_James
posts.cooked: I will say I very rarely use an actual computer when looking at websites so I can say there is some weird sizing things on mobile. On your home page none of the pictures fill up the black box. On your team history page the robots are either oddly cut off or when explaining the game as small as physically possible. In your about us page the YouTube video is oddly cropped as well.
And this is the exact kind of feedback I'm looking for! turns out that I might need to test it on more than just my laptop

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked: You can test mobile sizes on your laptop. Open your browsers developer console (ctrl-shift-i or right click and "inspect") then find the mobile size tool. Here it is highlighted in Firefox.
Hey, another Firefox user nice to see you! I knew about the button for a while, but now that I think about it, I haven't used it yet.

posts.name: Yehudan Rothstein
posts.cooked:
Hey last year I was head of the web in my team some of my projects are linked here FRC Team website https www excaliburfrc com https exclab excaliburfrc com https exclab scouting system https exclab scouting excaliburfrc com and more like a finance management system or strategy dashboard  

I found the best way to make your website elegant and nice is by generating a layout from AI tools  

I looked at your website and it’s an awesome way to start but getting to a perfect product is very hard and takes a lot of experience and time So for your case I would work with ChatGPT for making a detailed prompt for your website structure and layout then giving it to a website generating model like Bolt or Lovable they do a fantastic job at creating websites that look nice and have really good visual context  

Notice that they often use languages and frameworks like TS node vite and tailwind that are not just plain HTML CSS and JS This does require learning or having experience to edit them I guess you don’t want just to vibe code  

If you need any assistance you can personally contact me on chief or via our teams email and I will happily help with whatever you need

link_counts.title: ExcaLIB - Advanced WpilibJ Library for FRC Robotics

posts.name: Eli
posts.cooked: If you're looking for new things to add to your website, I recommend that you visit some other team's websites (such as 1678, 4481, or 6328). Look at what they've done and take a little bit of inspiration from their approaches to tailor it to your liking.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
On that note, if you're ever looking for inspiration like I was, the best FRC team website I've found is probably Adambots.  

I do believe design is really only 50% of the role here, with actual maintenance and writing/photos worth spending time viewing being the other half.  

Good luck! I love to see cool team websites.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: Test your website using browser inspector tools. I'd try it out on both Firefox and Chrome, and Safari if you have access to a Mac/Macbook. While I use Firefox as my daily browser, I use Chrome for web-dev as it has better tooling. Still, there’s a ton of useful tools in any browser. In the Network tool, you can see the size of every single resource that your browser receives on page load. The Robot Archive page is particularly egregious: it’s pulling 170 MB due to all of those embedded Google Slides. Here’s another method: add the loading="lazy" attribute to each <iframe> tag. This will defer loading the iframe until it’s scrolled into view. One more suggestion: keep large paragraphs (and lists) justified left, and cap their maximum width. This makes it easier to read. Good work so far!
How can I limit the maximum width of an element while making it responsive across different screen sizes, considering my limited coding knowledge from a 2017 source and Chat GPT assistance?
Hey, something from this thread that I can actually figure out how to implement (or at least it is Google-able enough that I can probably have ChatGPT help me with it).

They received positive feedback and are considering using a coding framework to address future issues due to their limited knowledge. They've tried DeepSite before but found its excessive code outputs difficult to handle. They suggest rewriting the code to be more elegant instead.
Probably doesn’t help that I have everything on the site loading as a PNG—I’m not an expert, and I don’t know how much that matters, but I’d guess it’s probably not a particularly efficient format.
The app should eliminate margins when it detects mobile devices to improve layout on smaller screens.
OK people it looks like it’s time for me to make a bunch of forks and pull requests or more accurately probably spend a lot of time watching a bunch of YouTube tutorials

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: Here’s a good place to start with lazy loading. (edit: forced link to be in English) This post covers the loading attribute and how to use it to control the loading of iframes. This post covers the loading attribute and how to use it to control the loading of iframes. W3Schools.com offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. MDN Web Docs provides information about Open Web technologies including HTML, CSS, and APIs for both Web sites and progressive web apps.

posts.cooked: Lazy loading has been implemented on the Robot archive. However, I did not implement lazy loading on the main page since I believe that iframes will always load automatically regardless.

I'm gonna go ahead and change those images to be .webp but want to use the  picture Element to fall back to PNG in older browsers (JPEG would probably make more sense for this, but I don't feel like converting everything for a third time...). I've got some personal stuff coming up so I won't probably be able to work on this for a few days, but rest assured it's in the works.
